trial_identification.studytitle: Treadmill Training in Infants At-Risk for Neuromotor Delay
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Infants at risk for neurodevelopmental delay with and without treadmill training: frequency of alternating steps and toe contacts

conditions.healthcondition: Infant born with low birth weight (<1500g).

interventions.interventions: Treadmill training; frequency: 5 days/week; duration: 8 minutes/session; belt speed: 0.2m/s. The intervention started when infants were able to produce 10 supported steps on a treadmill within 1 minute trial (as long as it happened before turning 13 months corrected age, if they were to be included in this study). Treadmill training continued until the infant was observed walking 3 independent steps over ground, or the infant turned 24 months corrected age.
interventions.comparator: The control group did not receive treadmill training. All families were visited on a monthly basis to videotape five 1-minute trials of the infants stepping while being supported on a treadmill.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome 1: Age of onset of independent walking.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: whenever families reported their infants being able to take 3 steps over ground.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome 2: percent of alternating steps.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: monthly from starting the training or entering the study until walking onset (termination of intervention), and 6 months follow-up for gait analysis.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome 3: percent of toe contact (Video analysis of foot placement at the initiation of the stance phase in the treadmill step).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: monthly from starting the training or entering the study until walking onset (termination of intervention), and 6 months follow-up for gait analysis.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Secondary outcome 1: Gross Motor Function Measure
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: Termination of the intervention: when the infant was observed walking 3 independent steps over ground. Same timepoint for the control group.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Mild to moderate hypo/hypertonia or developmental delay when examined by their pediatrician; no congenital musculoskeletal deficits or other genetic disorders.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Severe hypo/hypertonia, genetic disorders such as spina bifida or Down syndrome, and genetic musculoskeletal deficits.

trial_design.concealment: Recruitment via high risk clinics of local hospital, doctors referred potential subjects, and after checking exclusion/inclusion criteria, the assigned ID was entreted into a computer program for group allocation by a statistician unaware to which group the subject would be allocated (central randomisation)
trial_design.sequence: Randomisation was conducted via a computer program considering 3 stratification factors: age, gender, birth weight

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose of this study was to examine the potential benefits of treadmill training in infants who are at risk of having delays related to their movement development. In addition, previous research has suggested that there might be a relationship between how infants perform their steps on the treadmill and the age of onset of independent walking. Therefore, this has also been explored. Hypotheses: treadmill training in infants at risk for developmental delays may: a) lead to earlier onset of walking; b) increase the number of steps taken per minute; and c) improve correct foot positioning during stepping relative to an untrained control group.
